Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
#
# save as test1.ps1 and schedule it in cron
#
#  example: 
# * * * * * cd /home/peperud/test && pwsh test.ps1
#
[CmdLetBinding()]
param(
    [Parameter(ValueFromPipeLine = $true)]
    [string] $EchoThis = 'default echo'
)
begin {
    'Begin starts'
}
process {
    'Process starts'
    $EchoThis
}
end {
    'End starts'
}
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
```none
Begin starts
Process starts
default echo
End starts
```

Actual behavior
---------------
```none
Begin starts
End starts
```

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body:
When the script is run from `cron`, there is no input so the `process` block is never executed. Similarly, running for `cmd.exe` redirecting `stdin` to `nul` you see the same behaviour:
```
C:\temp>powershell -file doit.ps1
Begin starts
Process starts
default echo
End starts

C:\temp>powershell -file doit.ps1 < nul
Begin starts
End starts
```

comments.author: stknohg
comments.body:
@BrucePay 

Is there a workaround?
I tried using `-Command`(`-c`) parameter, it seems to work expected at first glance, but I can not be sure.

```powershell

```

comments.author: stknohg
comments.body: @BrucePay Thank you. But why does dot source operator work well?

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: Actually the dot is unnecessary but harmless. Simply invoking the script is sufficient.

title: process {} block not called when running from cron (linux)
